verses.text: Now in the twelfth month, which is the month of Adar, on the thirteenth day, when the king’s command and his decree were about to be carried out, on the very day that the enemies of the Jews hoped to gain power over them, the reverse happened—the Jews gained mastery over those who hated them.
verses.comment: This verse shows a reversal of fortunes—a recurring biblical theme where God’s people are saved at the moment of their greatest peril (see Exod. 14 for the Red Sea event).

verses.text: The Jews gathered together in their cities throughout all the provinces of King Xerxes to attack anyone who sought their harm. No one could stand against them, for the fear of them had fallen upon all peoples.
verses.comment: God’s people were granted favor and protection; similar language is found in Joshua 5:1, showing God’s providential care for His chosen.

verses.text: All the officials of the provinces, the satraps, the governors, and those who managed the king’s affairs helped the Jews, for the fear of Mordecai had fallen upon them.
verses.comment: Mordecai’s influence shows how the faithfulness of one leader can impact an entire nation (see also Gen. 41 for Joseph’s leadership in Egypt).

verses.text: For Mordecai was great in the king's palace, and his fame spread throughout all the provinces. For the man Mordecai continued to grow greater.
verses.comment: Mordecai’s exaltation recalls the way God lifts up the lowly who are faithful (see 1 Sam. 2:8).

verses.text: So the Jews struck down all their enemies with the sword, killing and destroying, and they did as they pleased to those who hated them.
verses.comment: There’s a clear parallel to the accounts of God granting victory to His people in Canaan.

verses.text: In the citadel of Susa alone, the Jews killed and destroyed five hundred men.
verses.comment: Susa serves as the royal city—a symbol of power now seeing God’s justice enacted.

verses.text: And they killed Parshandatha, Dalphon, Aspatha,
verses.comment: The enemies named here are the sons of Haman, symbolizing judgment against evil leadership.

verses.text: Poratha, Adalia, Aridatha,
verses.comment: These are among Haman's sons, emphasizing the fall of evil’s legacy.

verses.text: Parmashta, Arisai, Aridai, and Vaizatha—
verses.comment: Their complete defeat further shows the end of Haman's line, echoing God’s justice.

verses.text: the ten sons of Haman, the son of Hammedatha, the enemy of the Jews. But they did not lay their hands on the plunder.
verses.comment: Israel’s refusal to take plunder mirrors Saul’s failure in 1 Samuel 15; obedience is highlighted over material gain.

verses.text: That day the number of those killed in the citadel of Susa was reported to the king.
verses.comment: The king’s awareness underscores how even secular authorities became witness to God’s protection.

verses.text: The king said to Queen Esther, 'In the citadel of Susa the Jews have killed and destroyed five hundred men and also the ten sons of Haman. What have they done in the rest of the king’s provinces? Now what is your petition? It shall be granted to you. And what further is your request? It shall be done.'
verses.comment: The king’s eagerness to grant Esther’s request is a sign of divine favor, similar to the king’s favor toward Nehemiah (Neh. 2:4–6).

verses.text: Esther said, 'If it pleases the king, let the Jews who are in Susa be allowed to do tomorrow as they have done today. And let the ten sons of Haman be hanged on the gallows.'
verses.comment: Esther’s bold leadership mirrors the intercessory role of righteous leaders, anticipating the fullness of intercession in Christ (Heb. 7:25).

verses.text: So the king commanded this to be done; the decree was issued in Susa, and they hanged the ten sons of Haman.
verses.comment: Justice is fully executed at the king’s word—pointing forward to the day when God’s justice is complete.

verses.text: The Jews who were in Susa gathered again on the fourteenth day of the month of Adar and killed three hundred more men in Susa, but they did not lay hands on the plunder.
verses.comment: The consistent refusal to take plunder reinforces the spiritual nature of their deliverance—it was an act of justice, not greed.

verses.text: The rest of the Jews who were in the king's provinces also gathered to defend their lives and found relief from their enemies. They killed seventy-five thousand of those who hated them, but they did not lay their hands on the plunder.
verses.comment: This verse underscores the completeness of victory and restraint, paralleling the theme of sanctified warfare for the sake of God’s justice (Deut. 20:16–18).

verses.text: This was done on the thirteenth day of the month of Adar, and on the fourteenth day they rested and made it a day of feasting and gladness.
verses.comment: Feasting after deliverance draws on Israel’s tradition of commemorating salvation events with sacred meals—hinting at the deeper spiritual fulfillment in the Lord’s Supper.

verses.text: But the Jews who were in Susa assembled on both the thirteenth and fourteenth, and on the fifteenth day they rested and made it a day of feasting and joy.
verses.comment: Susa uniquely celebrates on a different day, reflecting how the practice of sacred days developed in the people of God.

verses.text: Therefore the Jews in the villages, who lived in the rural towns, keep the fourteenth day of the month of Adar as a day of joy and feasting, as a holiday, and as a day on which they send gifts of food to one another.
verses.comment: The communal sharing of gifts established a tradition of spiritual and material charity, foundational for later forms of Christian fellowship (Acts 2:44–46).

verses.text: Mordecai recorded these events, and he sent letters to all the Jews in all the provinces of King Xerxes, both near and far,
verses.comment: The written record highlights the importance of remembering salvation history, much like the later canonical Scriptures.

verses.text: to establish that they should celebrate annually the fourteenth and fifteenth days of the month of Adar,
verses.comment: An annual feast is inaugurated—echoing the pattern of liturgical commemoration found throughout Old and New Testament practice.

verses.text: as the days on which the Jews got relief from their enemies, and as the month that had been turned for them from sorrow into gladness and from mourning into a holiday; that they should make them days of feasting and joy, and of sending gifts of food to one another and gifts to the poor.
verses.comment: The union of celebration and care for the poor is a profound theological sign: God’s deliverance always bears fruit in charity (James 1:27).

verses.text: So the Jews agreed to do as they had started to do, and as Mordecai had written to them.
verses.comment: Obedience to divinely instituted remembrance is a central mark of God’s people, foreshadowing sacramental observance.

verses.text: For Haman the son of Hammedatha, the Agagite, the enemy of all the Jews, had plotted against the Jews to destroy them, and had cast Pur (that is, the lot), to crush and to destroy them.
verses.comment: The mention of ‘Pur’ is the root of Purim, underscoring how even chance is within God’s providence (Prov. 16:33).

verses.text: But when Esther came before the king, he gave orders in writing that the evil scheme which Haman had devised against the Jews should return upon his own head, and that he and his sons should be hanged on the gallows.
verses.comment: The reversal in this verse is a key biblical insight: God can turn evil intentions for the blessing of his people (cf. Gen. 50:20).

verses.text: Therefore they called these days Purim, after the word Pur. Therefore, because of all that was written in this letter, and what they had seen and what had happened to them,
verses.comment: The naming of the feast after ‘Pur’ highlights the Lord’s sovereignty even over events dictated by ‘chance’.

verses.text: the Jews bound themselves, their descendants, and all who joined them, to keep these two days every year, without fail, just as it was written and appointed.
verses.comment: The binding nature of the observance prefigures the way later generations would be called to keep holy days.

verses.text: And these days should be remembered and celebrated throughout every generation, every family, every province, and every city, that these days of Purim should not fail from among the Jews, nor the remembrance of them perish among their descendants.
verses.comment: The everlasting remembrance of deliverance ties the story to the perpetual memorial of salvation found in the new covenant.

verses.text: Then Queen Esther, the daughter of Abihail, and Mordecai the Jew, wrote with full authority to confirm this second letter about Purim.
verses.comment: The confirmation by leaders shows how spiritual authority is exercised for the guidance of the people.

verses.text: Letters were sent to all the Jews, to the one hundred twenty-seven provinces of the kingdom of Xerxes, with words of peace and truth,
verses.comment: The spreading of the ordinance to all provinces demonstrates unity and ecclesial continuity, echoing how the people of God are meant to be one.

verses.text: to establish these days of Purim at their appointed times, as Mordecai the Jew and Queen Esther had established for them, and as they had established for themselves and their descendants concerning matters of fasting and lamentation.
verses.comment: Notice the mention of both feasting and fasting—pointing to the pilgrim people’s rhythm of celebration and penance.

verses.text: The command of Esther established these customs of Purim, and it was recorded in writing.
verses.comment: The solemn establishment through written word anticipates the definitive role of Scripture and Tradition for passing on faith and practice in the redeemed community.
